title: How does the sky look like with infrared goggles at night? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends. If it’s clear and cloudless, it looks grey. I don’t think I have a photo of that. My camera does not have the resolution to resolve stars, and besides, the atmosphere is not transparent to thermal infra-red - what I think I see is a uniform brightness level from the upper atmosphere. I have a relatively cheap camera that does not have manual control of the gain (what in a normal camera would be the iris); it has auto-gain. What I can do is to freeze the current gain setting - point the camera at my foot on auto, freeze that, then look at the sky. I can’t just point it at the sky then adjust a knob to get a good picture. Which is a long-winded way of explaining why I don’t have a lot of these pictures to choose from, and if I did have a picture of a uniform brightness sky, it’s hard to tell apart from one with the lens shutter closed. The camera actually records a 320x240 pixel monochrome image of 10um infrared intensity with an image depth of about 12 bits. That is normally mapped onto a “hot iron” false-colour JPEG with a depth of 8 bits - it’s what people expect, and it looks cool, and it makes it easier to see heat losses. Cold things are black or blue, warm things are dull red through red, very hot things are yellow or white. The colours from heating iron in a forge, with the blue added in at the cold end. My camera has several false-colour palettes to choose from, including greyscale, but hot iron is the most common. Mapping is done in the camera, before it saves the JPEG. With more expensive cameras, you can save a raw image and post-process it. So the images you see like the one below are not “real” - they have been processed into something we can interpret. If it’s cloudy, you can see clouds - they are at a different temperature from the open sky. Where with the naked eye everything looks black, with the camera it looks more interesting.
